For example, in the task above, you can ask questions that reinforce number identification, such as: </span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#202020;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><ul class="lst-kix_list_1-0 start" style="padding:0;margin:0"><li style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.0;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";color:#202020;font-weight:400">“Which number is winning?”</span></li><li style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.0;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#202020;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">“What number did you roll?”</span></li></ul><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#202020;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#202020;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">You can also reinforce counting skills by asking students to order numbers based on the count sequence, as opposed to size. (Kindergarten students do learn that successive number names refer to a quantity that is one larger, but we will discuss that later.) The activity below describes how you can use number lines to support writing and identifying numbers as well as sequencing numbers.</span></p><p This learning is essential for connecting number names to quantity. The second cluster in the Counting & Cardinality domain is about making this connection. Let’s read the standards associated with this cluster, and then we’ll think through what they mean and how they look in practice.</span></p><p style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">they </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">sa</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">y</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> in </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">their </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">counting tells </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">them </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">the number of objects </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">they’ve </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">counted</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700"> </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">(i.e.</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> how many?).</span><span style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">K.CC.B.4b</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> While it may seem odd to see this spelled out in the standards, it’s an important understanding that may not be readily clear to students (i.e., </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">“I</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">f I start counting objects and end at the number </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">7</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">, there are </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">7</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> objects). As described in the Progression, “Prior to reaching this understanding, a student who is asked </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">‘</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">How many kittens?</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">’</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> may regard the counting performance itself as the answer, instead of answering with the cardinality of the set.”</span><sup style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"><a href="#ftnt6" id="ftnt_ref6">[6]</a></sup><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">So</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> if there are 4 kittens, a student might consider the answer to </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">“</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">how many?</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">”</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> to be the performance of counting 1, 2, 3, 4</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> rather than the cardinality of the set, which is 4. Students may need support in making the explicit connection that the last </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">number</span><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"> said represents the number of objects. Questions like, “How many kittens did you count?” followed by, “So, how many kittens are there?” might help make this connection.</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">In addition</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">, students who have </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">a lot of experience and discourse around counting different arrangements of objects </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">will more readily understand</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> that the number</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> of</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.</span><span style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">K.CC.B.4b</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> </span><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">In the lesson below, students count cubes to find how many and then arrange the cubes in different configurations and verify that the count is the same.</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Good counting and finding, everyone!  (Hold up a bag of non-connected cubes.)  Look at these cubes! I want to count how many I have of each color cube, but they are all mixed up!  What should I do?</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">S: Let’s dump them out and put the cubes that are the same color together.</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Good idea!  (As a whole group, work together to connect the same colored cubes.  Position the sticks of connected cubes vertically.)</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Now we can count how many of each color cube we have.  Let’s count the blue cubes.</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">S: There’s only 1 blue cube.</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Yes.  What card can we put under the blue cube to show that there is only one blue cube?</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">S: The number 1.  (Call on a student to choose the correct card and place it beneath the blue cube.)</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.1500000000000001;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">Continue until all of the numeral cards 1–5 are placed under a stick of cubes.</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.1500000000000001;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700"><task break></span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: (Turn the 5-cube stick horizontal.)  Do we have to change the numeral card for this stick of cubes?  (Provide wait time, and call on several students.  Be sure to ask the reason why or why not.)</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">S: No, because there are still 5 cubes, so the 5 card is still good.</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Should we count the cubes again?  (Provide wait time, and elicit several opinions.  Be sure to ask the reason why or why not.)</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span because you didn’t put any more cubes on or take any off; you just turned the stick.</span></p><p style="padding:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;line-height:1.1500000000000001;margin-right:0;margin-left:36pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";margin-top:0;orphans:2;margin-bottom:0;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">T: Okay.  You are ready to try this at your desk.  (Distribute style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">Students can work in pairs to scaffold their counting, and teachers should take care that at least one student in each pair is a confident counter and at least one student is a confident writer. Students can be provided with a number line to aid in writing the numbers. If the teacher is concerned that students cannot write the numbers independently s/he can write the quantities on post-it notes ahead of time and let the students choose the post it note that goes with each goody bag.</span></p></td></tr><tr style="height:0pt"><td colspan="1" rowspan="1" style="border-right-style:solid;padding:5pt 5pt 5pt style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">s important to point out that students should have experience thinking about the size of objects in relation to the number of objects. As noted in the commentary section for</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> the</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> “Goody Bags” </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">task above, </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">some bags should contain a small number of large objects and some should contain a large number of small objects. Experiences like this help students understand that small objects don’t “count less” than large objects.</span></p><h3 id="h.bum0saocvblc" style="padding-top:14pt;margin:0;color:#000000;font-weight:700;padding-left:0;font-size:14pt;padding-bottom:4pt;line-height:1.0;page-break-after:avoid;font-family:"Calibri";orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left;padding-right:0"><span>Subitizing</span></h3><p style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">Did you have to count? Or did you just “know”?</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">With lots of practice counting small groups of objects, with varying arrangements, students begin to recognize the cardinalities of small groups without having to count each object in the group. For example, a student might roll a three using a six-sided cube and know that three dots is the number 3, without </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">needing to </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">count the three dots individually, as in Picture 1 above. This is referred to as </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700">perceptual </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700">subitizing</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">. Perceptual subitizing is important because it leads to </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700">conceptual subitizing</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">, </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">the ability to recognize</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> that a collection of objects is composed of subcollections</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> and </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">that </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">by quickly combining the cardinalities of the subcollections</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> you can find the cardinality of the collection. In other words, </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">a number is composed of other numbers</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">. For example, a student might see a domino with two subsets, each with a </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">cardinality</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> of 2, and know the cardinality for the whole set is 4.</span><sup style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"><a href="#ftnt8" id="ftnt_ref8">[8]</a></sup><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"> </span></p><p 2</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">Subitizing is important because it supports addition and subtraction strategies, including </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">“</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">counting on,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">”</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> and eventually leads to more sophisticated methods for supporting all four operations. We’ll explore conceptual subitizing more when we discuss decomposing numbers in the Operations & Algebraic Thinking cluster K.OA.A. </span></p><h2 id="h.gkkmya6lukr2" style="padding-top:18pt;margin:0;color:#000000;font-weight:700;padding-left:0;font-size:18pt;padding-bottom:4pt;line-height:1.0;page-break-after:avoid;font-family:"Calibri";orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left;padding-right:0"><span>Laying a foundation for “counting on”</span></h2><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">The foundation for “counting on”</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">—</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">an addition and subtraction strategy more sophisticated than counting all</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">—</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">begins in K</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">indergarten</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">, and there are s</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">everal concepts related to counting and cardinality </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">that </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">support “counting on” strategies. Students have to have facility with counting forward from a given number</span><span style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">K.CC.A.2</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> as well as with determining the cardinality of a group of objects. Equally important is understanding that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.</span><span style="vertical-align:super;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">K.CC.B.4c</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> Students combine these understandings in order to understand “one more” and “one less” without having to recount the number of objects in the group to which an object was added or subtracted. Relating each successive number name to “one more” or “one less” </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">in a concrete way can help students grasp the concept</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">. </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">For </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">example</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">,</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> in the lesson below, </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">your </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">students</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> can</span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400"> work with linking cubes to discover that each number tower is one more than the previous number tower. The activity asks </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">them</span><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"> to draw “one more” cube on each tower so that the number of cubes in the tower is equal to the number beneath the tower. Students also use the language of “one more” to relate successive numbers.</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";color:#000000;font-weight:400">When students begin </span><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">doing this</span><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:700;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">Materials</span></p><p style="padding-top:0pt;margin:0;color:#000000;padding-left:0;font-size:12pt;padding-bottom:19pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left;padding-right:0"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">Paper bags and marbles (or some other counter, as long as it is relatively noisy).</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:700;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">Actions</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">(Whole-class version) The teacher secretly places between 1 and 10 marbles in a paper bag, then shows the bag to the class. After shaking it enough times for students to hear the marbles inside, and 4 or 5 students guess how many marbles are in the bag. The teacher writes the guesses on the board. Afterwards the contents of the bag are revealed and counted out. The teacher writes the number representing the total on the board, and the students then help sort their guesses into less than, greater than, or equal to the number of marbles in the bag. The game repeats until everyone has had a chance to guess at least once.</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:700;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"><task break></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:700;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">(Small group version) This works like the class version but one student in a group fill the bag with marbles themselves and the rest of the group tries to guess the number. With this variation it is practical to allow the students to both hear and feel the marbles inside the bag before they make their guess.</span></p></td></tr><tr style="height:0pt"><td colspan="1" One more is seven. One more is eight. One more is nine. So nine is greater than six. Okay?”</span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:700"><task break></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:700;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal">“Well, when I see the number line I see six comes before nine.” </span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;height:12pt;text-align:left"><span style="color:#000000;font-weight:400;text-decoration:none;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-style:normal"></span></p><p style="padding:0;margin:0;color:#000000;font-size:12pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";line-height:1.0;orphans:2;widows:2;text-align:left"><span style="font-size:11pt;font-family:"Arial";font-weight:400">“This many fingers is six (shows six fingers).
